title: How to Make Scouring Powder at Home

steps.headline: Add 1/2 cup (118.3 g) of baking soda to a bowl.
steps.description: Baking soda can be used as a scouring powder on its own, or you can add extra ingredients to make your powder more powerful. Either way, you'll want baking soda to be the base of your scouring powder. This will be enough scouring powder for about 1-2 uses.

steps.headline: Include 1 tbsp (14.8 g) of borax for a thorough clean.
steps.description: Borax is a natural mineral that can enhance the cleaning power of your powder. It helps lift off stubborn soap scum or residue, making it great to use in homemade scouring powders. For everyday cleaning, borax is not always necessary. However, it may take some of the elbow grease out of your cleaning task. Borax also works great to remove strong odors.

steps.headline: Add 1/4 cup (59.2 g) of salt if you need an abrasive cleaner.
steps.description: If you have very stubborn residue and need something to deeply penetrate the stain or spot, consider mixing regular table salt into your ingredients. The granules add some scrubbing power to your powder, so you can easily remove tough stains. If you are worried about scratching your surfaces, you do not need to use salt.

steps.headline: Mix in about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) (14.8 g) of dried herbs for a gentle cleanser.
steps.description: Dried herbs help naturally clean and disinfect your surfaces. They also add smell and strength to your cleaner. Use herbs such as lavender, dried rosemary, and lemon or orange zest. For best results, select dried, organic herbs. You can use any herb or flower you’d like.

steps.headline: Drip in 5-10 drops of essential oil for a touch of aromatherapy.
steps.description: Essential oils smell amazing and help to clean tough stains or soap scum. Use essential oil such as lemon, orange, tea tree, or rosemary for best results. These oils are known to help clean and disinfect. While essential oils are optional for your scouring powder, they make your bathroom or kitchen smell amazing. You can also use essential oils including lavender and eucalyptus.

steps.headline: Grate 1/4 of a soap bar if you want a bubbly, sudsy clean.
steps.description: When cleaning your bathroom or sink, sometimes a bit of bubble action can help remove stains or residue. Chop off about 1/4 from the end of your soap bar, and use a kitchen grater to create soap shavings. Then, add your shavings for a touch of bubbles. Keep in mind that this is optional. You can achieve a thorough clean without adding soap, though it helps lift off stubborn residue.

steps.headline: Mix the ingredients together using a spoon.
steps.description: Combine the ingredients in any order you’d like, as they will all get mixed together. Continue stirring for about 30 seconds or so to ensure the additives are thoroughly combined. You can start with the baking soda, add other dry ingredients, then drip in your essential oil last.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture into an air-tight container, such as a shaker.
steps.description: You can use nearly any container with an airtight seal, such as a glass jar or Tupperware. However, a shaker jar works great to easily distribute your scouring powder across your surface. Place a funnel at the top of your jar to ensure you don’t spill any, and fill up your container to the top. If you are making a large batch, you can use multiple containers to store your scouring powder.

steps.headline: Wet your surface with a bit of water.
steps.description: Adding some water helps lubricate the surface, so you can easily scrub it. You can fill up a cup with some water from your faucet, and pour it over top. You can also use a washcloth. Wet the washcloth and squeeze the water over the top of your surface.

steps.headline: Pour some lemon juice over top of the surface if you need a deep clean.
steps.description: While this is optional, lemon juice can help remove the most stubborn stains. Cut a fresh lemon in half, and squeeze the juice over top of your surface. This is a great way to use up any lemons that may be going bad.

steps.headline: Sprinkle a light, even layer of scouring powder over the surface.
steps.description: After you’ve applied your water and/or lemon juice, take your shaker container and sift the powder over top of the surface you want to clean. You only need a small amount to deeply clean your surface. Aim to have a bit of powder over every area you want to clean. You can always add more as needed.

steps.headline: Scrub the surface with a scrubbing brush or sponge.
steps.description: Grab a soft scrub brush or sponge with a scrubbing side. Rub either option over top of your scouring powder in small, circular motions. You can work in 3–5 in (7.6–12.7 cm) sections at a time for a thorough scrub.

steps.headline: Rinse the surface with hot water to wipe away any residue.
steps.description: Once your surface is clean, get a fresh, clean washcloth and hold it under hot water from your faucet. Then, wipe down the surface with the washcloth to get rid of any remaining powder, dirt, or debris. Hot water works best to lift up any stubborn soap scum.

text: Mixing Your Powder Add 1/2 cup (118.3 g) of baking soda to a bowl. Baking soda can be used as a scouring powder on its own, or you can add extra ingredients to make your powder more powerful. Either way, you'll want baking soda to be the base of your scouring powder. This will be enough scouring powder for about 1-2 uses. Include 1 tbsp (14.8 g) of borax for a thorough clean. Borax is a natural mineral that can enhance the cleaning power of your powder. It helps lift off stubborn soap scum or residue, making it great to use in homemade scouring powders. For everyday cleaning, borax is not always necessary. However, it may take some of the elbow grease out of your cleaning task. Borax also works great to remove strong odors. Add 1/4 cup (59.2 g) of salt if you need an abrasive cleaner. If you have very stubborn residue and need something to deeply penetrate the stain or spot, consider mixing regular table salt into your ingredients. The granules add some scrubbing power to your powder, so you can easily remove tough stains. If you are worried about scratching your surfaces, you do not need to use salt. Mix in about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) (14.8 g) of dried herbs for a gentle cleanser. Dried herbs help naturally clean and disinfect your surfaces. They also add smell and strength to your cleaner. Use herbs such as lavender, dried rosemary, and lemon or orange zest. For best results, select dried, organic herbs. You can use any herb or flower you’d like. Drip in 5-10 drops of essential oil for a touch of aromatherapy. Essential oils smell amazing and help to clean tough stains or soap scum. Use essential oil such as lemon, orange, tea tree, or rosemary for best results. These oils are known to help clean and disinfect. While essential oils are optional for your scouring powder, they make your bathroom or kitchen smell amazing. You can also use essential oils including lavender and eucalyptus. Grate 1/4 of a soap bar if you want a bubbly, sudsy clean. When cleaning your bathroom or sink, sometimes a bit of bubble action can help remove stains or residue. Chop off about 1/4 from the end of your soap bar, and use a kitchen grater to create soap shavings. Then, add your shavings for a touch of bubbles. Keep in mind that this is optional. You can achieve a thorough clean without adding soap, though it helps lift off stubborn residue. Mix the ingredients together using a spoon. Combine the ingredients in any order you’d like, as they will all get mixed together. Continue stirring for about 30 seconds or so to ensure the additives are thoroughly combined. You can start with the baking soda, add other dry ingredients, then drip in your essential oil last. Pour the mixture into an air-tight container, such as a shaker. You can use nearly any container with an airtight seal, such as a glass jar or Tupperware. However, a shaker jar works great to easily distribute your scouring powder across your surface. Place a funnel at the top of your jar to ensure you don’t spill any, and fill up your container to the top. If you are making a large batch, you can use multiple containers to store your scouring powder. Using the Scouring Powder Wet your surface with a bit of water. Adding some water helps lubricate the surface, so you can easily scrub it. You can fill up a cup with some water from your faucet, and pour it over top. You can also use a washcloth. Wet the washcloth and squeeze the water over the top of your surface. Pour some lemon juice over top of the surface if you need a deep clean. While this is optional, lemon juice can help remove the most stubborn stains. Cut a fresh lemon in half, and squeeze the juice over top of your surface. This is a great way to use up any lemons that may be going bad. Sprinkle a light, even layer of scouring powder over the surface. After you’ve applied your water and/or lemon juice, take your shaker container and sift the powder over top of the surface you want to clean. You only need a small amount to deeply clean your surface. Aim to have a bit of powder over every area you want to clean. You can always add more as needed. Scrub the surface with a scrubbing brush or sponge. Grab a soft scrub brush or sponge with a scrubbing side. Rub either option over top of your scouring powder in small, circular motions. You can work in 3–5 in (7.6–12.7 cm) sections at a time for a thorough scrub. Rinse the surface with hot water to wipe away any residue. Once your surface is clean, get a fresh, clean washcloth and hold it under hot water from your faucet. Then, wipe down the surface with the washcloth to get rid of any remaining powder, dirt, or debris. Hot water works best to lift up any stubborn soap scum.

Baking soda can be used as a scouring powder on its own, or you can add extra ingredients to make your powder more powerful.
Either way, you'll want baking soda to be the base of your scouring powder.
This will be enough scouring powder for about 1-2 uses.
Include 1 tbsp (14.8 g) of borax for a thorough clean.
Borax is a natural mineral that can enhance the cleaning power of your powder.
It helps lift off stubborn soap scum or residue, making it great to use in homemade scouring powders.
For everyday cleaning, borax is not always necessary.
However, it may take some of the elbow grease out of your cleaning task.
Borax also works great to remove strong odors.
Add 1/4 cup (59.2 g) of salt if you need an abrasive cleaner.
If you have very stubborn residue and need something to deeply penetrate the stain or spot, consider mixing regular table salt into your ingredients.
The granules add some scrubbing power to your powder, so you can easily remove tough stains.
If you are worried about scratching your surfaces, you do not need to use salt.
Mix in about 1 tablespoon (15 ml) (14.8 g) of dried herbs for a gentle cleanser.
Dried herbs help naturally clean and disinfect your surfaces.
They also add smell and strength to your cleaner.
Use herbs such as lavender, dried rosemary, and lemon or orange zest.
For best results, select dried, organic herbs.
You can use any herb or flower you’d like.
Drip in 5-10 drops of essential oil for a touch of aromatherapy.
Essential oils smell amazing and help to clean tough stains or soap scum.
Use essential oil such as lemon, orange, tea tree, or rosemary for best results.
These oils are known to help clean and disinfect.
While essential oils are optional for your scouring powder, they make your bathroom or kitchen smell amazing.
You can also use essential oils including lavender and eucalyptus.

When cleaning your bathroom or sink, sometimes a bit of bubble action can help remove stains or residue.
Chop off about 1/4 from the end of your soap bar, and use a kitchen grater to create soap shavings.
Then, add your shavings for a touch of bubbles.
Keep in mind that this is optional.
You can achieve a thorough clean without adding soap, though it helps lift off stubborn residue.
Mix the ingredients together using a spoon.
Combine the ingredients in any order you’d like, as they will all get mixed together.
Continue stirring for about 30 seconds or so to ensure the additives are thoroughly combined.
You can start with the baking soda, add other dry ingredients, then drip in your essential oil last.
Pour the mixture into an air-tight container, such as a shaker.
You can use nearly any container with an airtight seal, such as a glass jar or Tupperware.
However, a shaker jar works great to easily distribute your scouring powder across your surface.
Place a funnel at the top of your jar to ensure you don’t spill any, and fill up your container to the top.
If you are making a large batch, you can use multiple containers to store your scouring powder.
Using the Scouring Powder Wet your surface with a bit of water.
Adding some water helps lubricate the surface, so you can easily scrub it.
You can fill up a cup with some water from your faucet, and pour it over top.
You can also use a washcloth.
Wet the washcloth and squeeze the water over the top of your surface.
Pour some lemon juice over top of the surface if you need a deep clean.
While this is optional, lemon juice can help remove the most stubborn stains.
Cut a fresh lemon in half, and squeeze the juice over top of your surface.
This is a great way to use up any lemons that may be going bad.
Sprinkle a light, even layer of scouring powder over the surface.
After you’ve applied your water and/or lemon juice, take your shaker container and sift the powder over top of the surface you want to clean.
You only need a small amount to deeply clean your surface.
Aim to have a bit of powder over every area you want to clean.
You can always add more as needed.
Scrub the surface with a scrubbing brush or sponge.
Grab a soft scrub brush or sponge with a scrubbing side.
Rub either option over top of your scouring powder in small, circular motions.
You can work in 3–5 in (7.6–12.7 cm) sections at a time for a thorough scrub.
Rinse the surface with hot water to wipe away any residue.
Once your surface is clean, get a fresh, clean washcloth and hold it under hot water from your faucet.
Then, wipe down the surface with the washcloth to get rid of any remaining powder, dirt, or debris.
Hot water works best to lift up any stubborn soap scum.
tyn_section: 1 tbsp (14.8 g) dried herbs, flowers, or spices
1/4 of a bar of soap, grated
1/4 cup (59.2 g) of regular table salt
